required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility Study of a 60 Minute Rapid Infusion Rituximab Protocol in Patients With B-cell Malignancies
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Hypersensitivity Reactions and Feasibility of a 60 Minute Rapid Infusion Rituximab Protocol in Patients With B-Cell Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL) and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) at a Comprehensive Cancer Center

lead_sponsor.agency: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

clinical_study.source: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of a 60 minute rapid infusion rituximab protocol in the institution's outpatient infusion center.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Grade III and IV Hypersensitivity Reactions
primary_outcome.time_frame: Every 15 minutes from start of infusion until completion, for up to 1 hour

secondary_outcome.measure: Time Savings of a 60 Minute Infusion Versus Predicted Infusion Time Using Standard Second Dose Titration Schedule
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Determined from difference in expected time by package insert administration and actual time on day of treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Demonstrate Nursing Satisfaction for Administration of Rapid Infusion Over Standard Titration Practice
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 months, as a before and after infusion survey
secondary_outcome.description: Surveys were given to nurses in the outpatient infusion center to measure their satisfaction with the administration of the rapid infusion rate compared to standard titration practice.

clinical_study.condition: Indolent or Intermediate Grade B-cell Malignancy

intervention.description: Dose 2 of Rituximab IVPB will be started at a rate of 100 mg/hr for the first 15 minutes. If tolerated, the remainder of the bag will be infused over 45 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18-89
- Diagnosis of indolent or intermediate grade B-cell malignancy
- Patients receiving rituximab-based therapy at a dose of 375mg/m2, regardless of weight
- First dose given within 3 months of the second dose
- Infusion scheduled for outpatient administration at The Arthur G. James Cancer Hospital and Richard J. Solove Research Institute
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of aggressive lymphoma
- Absolute lymphocyte count > 10 x 103 cells/ÂµL
- New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification Grade II or greater congestive heart failure
- Enrolled on another clinical trial
- Allergy to murine-containing medications
- Grade III or IV hypersensitivity reaction during the initial infusion of rituximab
- Prisoners
- Pregnant women
- Mentally or physically unable to give consent

facility.name: The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patients were enrolled from October 2010 to April 2013

outcome.description: Surveys were given to nurses in the outpatient infusion center to measure their satisfaction with the administration of the rapid infusion rate compared to standard titration practice.

outcome.population: Post infusion surveys were collected and de-identified by assignment of an individual nurse identification number

reported_events.desc: The study utilized the National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events version 4.0 for adverse event reporting.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
